data.name: Applied Crafting
data.data: Crafting can be a pain. So why not automate it? These can hold a single pattern each. However, if you place an ME interface against it, you can use it to craft any of the patterns in it. You can use multiple with the same MA, and given how expensive they are now, that might be a good idea. These do NOT require a channel, but do require network access.
data.title: Applied Crafting

data.name: Applied Greg?
data.data:
ME Buses are combination of technology and...other technology. Don't give me that look, it is, OK? With these, you can now directly I/O items between GregTech multiblock and ME network. They have §osignificantly§r less lag, so please start using them as soon as possible on servers.

You just pop off your GT bus + ME bus or ME interface combination, and replace both with the new bus and connect a ME cable directly to it. It uses 1 channel, same as the other options.

The output bus and hatch have limited output space. If you need more, you can upgrade them either by crafting them with storage components or putting a cell inside. A digital singularity cell will make the cache near infinite.

Note that the output bus must eject each item from its cache §oin order§r. If it cannot eject the topmost item, it will be stuck and cannot eject any other items.

If voiding is turned off, the multiblock will not void when the ME Outputs are full.

[note]For usage in some machines, i.e. the advanced assembly line, the configured item must be in the first slot in order for the multi to work.[/note]
data.title: Applied Greg?

data.name: Autocrafting Magic Stuff
data.data:
The Arcane Assembler works like a combination of the Molecular Assembler and the Arcane Workbench, allowing you to autocraft anything crafted in the latter. You need to link a vis relay through the network to supply essentia to it, and a Knowledge Core with recipes on it for to work. Additionally, you can add vis discount gear into the interface to take advantage of the discount. The base discount starts at 20%. For each Acceleration card, the time taken will reduce by 20%, and increase power used by 50%. For every point of warp on the discount gear, the power costs increase by 15%.

The knowledge core holds up to 21 patterns for use in the Arcane Assembler, but you need a new assembler for every knowledge core if you want to autocraft more than that.

To encode the patterns, you need a Knowledge Inscriber. It works exactly as you would expect. It doesn't connect to the network, so it doesn't need a channel. If you want to erase a pattern select it and the save icon should become erase instead.
data.title: Autocrafting Magic Stuff

data.name: Automating Crafting
data.data: Is a component of the crafting CPU multiblock. This particular block provides the CPU with no additional features, but can be used as a "filler" block and as a crafting ingredient for the crafting storage, monitor and co-processing units.
data.title: Automating Crafting

data.name: Basic Terminals
data.data:
The ME Terminal is an interface which gives you access to an ME network's networked storage. It has the ability to sort and search, as well as filter by using a view cell.

The ME Crafting Terminal is the upgraded version of the ME terminal which has an integrated crafting grid with access to an ME network's networked storage.

The ME Interface Terminal gives remote access to all interface pattern slots on your network separated by which type of machine they are on. It will show the type of machine in the terminal, however you can name the ME interface in the inscriber or an anvil to alter the name displayed in the ME interface terminal. If you use Ender Chests to send stuff elsewhere to be processed a lot, this may help with reducing confusion. You can also search for a specific device.
data.title: Basic Terminals

data.name: Beam Me Up, Scotty
data.data:
If you want to teleport stuff around using these, you'll need a drive in the SIOP, and at least 6 pylons hooked up. The pylons need to indicate the X, Y and Z dimensions, with you needing 1 more than you would think. If the efficiency goes below 100%, the AE cost will balloon enormously, so add more pylons to counteract that. After using a redstone signal to activate the SIOP, the blocks will be moved to the spatial IO dim, and the drive will move to the output, so you can send it somewhere else. This is very important to do properly if you want to use it as a teleporter. Otherwise, you can get stuck there. Your network will need to be able to hold all the power needed to teleport at once, so you'll need at least one energy cell. You can only have one Pylon setup per controller, so consider putting them on a subnetwork.

Using 2 in the X and Z dimensions and 3 in the Y will give you a 1x2x1 teleporter to teleport yourself. You'll want a SIOP port on each side for sending and for receiving. But you'll still need to design a redstone contraption to activate them properly!

Read this if you want to know more about spatial IO in general, and larger setups: [url]https://old.reddit.com/r/feedthebeast/comments/3c2b2r/a_treatise_on_nocheat_smp_ae2_spatial_io/[/url]
Also see this if you want to see a fancy teleporter: [url]https://old.reddit.com/r/feedthebeast/comments/2mhrf8/ae2_spatial_transporters/[/url]

[warn]Spatial cells, once used, will only work in the XYZ dimensions first used, with no way to format or recraft. Test in creative first![/warn]

[warn]Expect your world to lag for a second after using, blame AE.[/warn]
data.title: Beam Me Up, Scotty
data.tooltip:
Beam Me Up, Scotty
Prequest requests:
AE Spatial Storage1
AE Spatial Storage5

data.name: Bundled AE Channels
data.data:
P2P tunnels. You'll probably want a bunch of them! They act as teleport points from one place to another for the contained information.

They can pack up to 32 channels into 1 channel and transport those to the destination P2P bus. Each P2P tunnel requires 1 free channel. P2P connections cannot be nested, but one transport cable can carry multiple P2P connections. For a normal fluix cable, that's 4 P2P connections, and 16 for dense.

You can use separate cables to connect input P2Ps to the controller and to transport from the controller to around your base, allowing for 32 output P2Ps on one dense cable. Alternatively you can use an entirely separate controller as a transport network.

Generally, you'll want to have the first point be one side of an ME Controller block (remember you can add more!), and the other where some of your machines are.

A nice online guide can be found at [url]https://wiki.gtnewhorizons.com/wiki/Applied_Energistics_2[/url] under P2P tunnels.

If you want to use one of the P2P tunnels for something §oother§r than ME channels, use an applicable item on the center of the face of the tunnel, (for example, a GT cable for GT EU, redstone for RS signal, an RF conduit for RF, a torch for light, a bucket for fluid, a chest for items, or an OC cable for OC) and it will convert to that type, even if you pick it up. Use a fluix cable to change it back.
data.title: Bundled AE Channels

data.name: Cables
data.data:
To have access to your applied energistics network from your entire base, you'll need cables. A lot of them. For now, the basic ones will do, but eventually, you'll end up using dense cables and p2p channels. Glass and Covered cables are functionally identical, just different in looks. Each can carry 8 channels. Quartz fibers don't carry channels but can carry energy. This is useful for providing power from your main network to independent subnetworks.

You can also color your cables - cables with different colors will not connect, so those can be used to expand network capacity by running parallel cables. Only fluix colored cables connect to all other colors. Later it will probably be more efficient to use P2P channels to jam a bunch of channels into 1.

Anchors are like covers, keeping things from connecting when you don't want them to.
data.title: Cables

data.name: Cards for AE2 Nerds!
data.data:
[quest]Equal Distribution, Fake Crafting, Locking, and Advanced Blocking Cards![/quest]

§6Equal Distribution Card:§r

The Equal Distribution Card will evenly divide a cell's capacity between types or partitions.

§6Fake Crafting Card:§r

The Fake Crafting Card will tell your ME System to complete a craft without expecting the final resulting item.

This can be handy for creating fake patterns for entire multiblocks or setups by collecting the individual items needed in one craft.

The card can only be inserted into:

§cME Dual Interface
ME Interface
P2P Tunnel - ME Dual Interface§r

§6Locking Card:§r

The Locking Card allows an interface to optionally block new crafts from being started for one of the following conditions:

§cWhile Redstone is low
While Redstone is high
After a craft has been pushed, until a redstone pulse is received
After a craft has been pushed, until the results have returned to the same interface§r

§6Advanced Blocking Card:§r

The Advanced Blocking Card is able to ignore non-consumables in a subnet for more complicated automations.

In a standard subnet, where two interfaces are facing each other, the Advanced Blocking Card is to be §9placed on the §lsubnet interface.§f
data.title: Cards for AE2 Nerds!
data.tooltip:
Cards for AE2 Nerds!
Prequest requests:
Deck of Cards

data.name: Centi-vis in your network
data.data: You can use this device to either transfer the contents (CV) of a Vis Relay to another vis relay, an Arcane Assembler, or an Arcane Crafting Terminal. Either way, place the relay on the device (and send some CV to it), and use the memory card to link to the second device. If you send it to another Vis Relay Interface, you'll obviously need another Vis Relay on the other side.
data.title: Centi-vis in your network
data.tooltip:
Centi-vis in your network
Prequest requests:
For Fluid Recipes

data.name: Co-Processing
data.data:
Component of the crafting CPU which provides additional item delivery from the CPU to the ME Interface for crafting.

This can be used to make more assemblers active in parallel for the job, and thus increase overall crafting speed. These only help if your setup has steps properly separated, so the system can run multiple tasks in parallel, or even split the same pattern across multiple interfaces.
data.title: Co-Processing

data.name: Co-Processing x16
data.data: For an even more compact crafting CPU.
data.title: Co-Processing x16

data.name: Co-Processing x4
data.data: Your crafting CPU is massive and still can't keep up? Don't worry, we have a custom solution for that!
data.title: Co-Processing x4

data.name: Crafting Input Proxy
data.data:
You have mastered both interdimensional transportation and wallsharing, why not combine them?

You can link both crafting input bus/buffer to proxies with data sticks and use it to process patterns with multiple machines, as if you are wallsharing them, but without actually wallsharing them.

[note]Maybe this can reduce lag?[/note]
data.title: Crafting Input Proxy
data.tooltip:
Crafting Input Proxy
Prequest requests:
Assembling on Steroids
Waterproof Tech
Ultimate Voltages Require Ultimate Lubricant™!

data.name: Crafting Monitor
data.data: Component of the crafting CPU which displays the top level job and its current progress so you can monitor at a glance how your crafting jobs are progressing.
data.title: Crafting Monitor

data.name: Cribs
data.data:
As your researches for Applied Greg continued, you found a way to combine ME interface's pattern processing ability with input buses, §lcrafting input buses§r! Now, you can directly place patterns into input bus. However, input buses lacked sufficient item space and computational power to process items coming from your ME network. Thus, you added additional storage and circuits.

You can even place non-consumable items like lenses, molds inside!! However, consumable items won't do anything.

But, still you lack enough technology to process fluids, they are just not good for electronics.

Crafting input bus is fully isolated from other buses/hatches, so you may have to change your patterns.

[warn]Crafting input proxy[/warn] will let you wallshare multiblocks without actually wallsharing them. §lUIV-Tier§r

[warn]Crafting input buffer[/warn] will be §9§owaterproof§r. §lUEV-Tier§r
data.title: Cribs

data.name: Cut the Power!
data.data: The ME Toggle Bus allows you to cut off access through a cable if it doesn't receive a redstone signal. The inverted version is, well, inverted. It must be placed between the cables, like a Quartz Fiber.
data.title: Cut the Power!
data.tooltip:
Cut the Power!
Prequest requests:
Redstone Based on Storage Level

data.name: Deck of Cards
data.data:
§rThese cards add additional functionality to certain devices or fixtures. They specify what devices they work on in the tooltip.

§6Redstone Card:§r

§rThe Redstone Card adds redstone interactivity to the devices it can be used on, with the following options:§r

§cAlways active
Active with redstone signal
Active without redstone signal
Activate once per pulse

§r§6Capacity Card: §f

§rThe Capacity Card adds more slots for items that use them.

§rIf you add this to an Export Bus, an icon is added to select item priority.

§6Crafting Card: §f

§rThe Crafting Card allows you to automatically request autocrafting of items.

§9In an ME Interface:§f

§rIf you put in items to be stocked, if there aren't enough, it'll craft them until it reaches the selected amount.

§rThese crafts are being stocked for recipes that the ME Interface has.§r

[note]If you want them to be seen by the network, you'll need to put a storage bus on the ME Interface.[/note]

§9In an ME Level Emitter:

§e§aFirst Mode:§f§r §UIt'll emit a redstone signal while the specific item is being crafted.§r

§e§aSecond Mode:§r§r§r§r It will emit a redstone signal once a crafting job for the item has been requested,§r [warn]but it won't send the items to be crafted.[/warn]

§rThis is useful if you're using a dummy pattern, and are using the level emitter to tell something else to happen.

§rYou still need to get the item(s) requested back into the system so it doesn't tie up a crafting CPU though.

§9In an ME Export Bus:§f

§rIt'll attempt to send whatever item(s) are selected in the export bus' GUI.

§e§aFirst Mode:§f§r It'll§r send available items first, then create crafting jobs for the rest.

§e§aSecond Mode:§f§r It will only send crafted items.

§6Acceleration Card:§f

§rThe Acceleration Card makes the device/fixture work faster.

§r[note]You'll probably want a lot of these.[/note]

§6Inverter Card:§f

§rThe Inverter Card allows you to invert the item filter of certain fixtures.

§6Fuzzy Card:§f

§rThe Fuzzy Card allows you to apply fuzzy logic to filtering to allow items with different NBT or damage data to be counted as the same. This is different from metadata.

§rIf you just want it to be fuzzy for NBT, set to §9Match Any.§f§f

§rIf it is set to §c99%§f§r, it will work on anything that is damaged. You can use the Inverter Card to reverse this.
data.title: Deck of Cards
data.tooltip:
Deck of Cards

data.name: Getting Your First Processors
data.data: There are 3 different ways to make AE2 processors. First, there's the AE2 Inscribers, which are slow, hold one of each item at a time, require inputs (and output) from specific directions, but can be sped up with cards. Second, there's the Advanced Inscribers, which are similar, but allow stacking, and do not require specific directions. Lastly, there's GT Assemblers (and later the multiblock) which can be very fast, but require a fluid input, and consume more power. Get 8 of each one for now.

You might find yourself setting up complicated systems involving many storage buses with differing priorities. To make it less tedious, grab a priority card!

This tool allows you to set many buses to the same priority with a single click... but better yet, it also features §nincrement and decrement modes!§r Every time you click on a bus, the priority will be set to one higher/lower than the previous bus you clicked, so setting up large arrays of descending priorities is a breeze.

For more details on AE2, check out [url]https://wiki.gtnewhorizons.com/wiki/Applied_Energistics_2[/url].

data.name: Imma Chargin' My...
data.data:
Charged certus quartz is one of the basic components for a lot of AE recipes. Just mix some certus quartz and redstone dust to get charged certus quartz dust.

Use the autoclave to make crystals. Or if you have lots of sodium, you can use the chemical reactor recipe. You can also make the charger to go directly from crystal to charged crystal, but it's not very fast. The charger can connect directly to a GT cable or a fluix cable from the bottom.

[note]Note that some recipes only have a chance of producing a charged crystal, which is true of many of these.[/note]
data.title: Imma Chargin' My...

data.name: Inserting Items Into the Network
data.data:
Pulls items from the inventory it is pointed at and places them into the ME network's networked storage. You can specify which items it will pull out via the UI, else it tries to pull out any item in the adjacent inventory. The ME import bus will attempt to import any possible options, even if 1 or more of the configured items cannot be stored. This is the functional opposite of the ME export bus.

When your machines are very fast, it's better to have them output directly into an ME interface instead, since that works instantly.
data.title: Inserting Items Into the Network
data.tooltip:
Inserting Items Into the Network

data.name: Insurgence
data.data:
Is your infusion very slow? And, alas, to resolve that you need a world accelerator. That probably causes a lot of lag.

Well no longer! Try out the new Infusion Interceptor. Read more about it on the Thaumic Insurgence page in your Thaumonomicon.
data.title: Insurgence

data.name: Interfacing with Inventories
data.data:
The ME Storage Bus, when attached to another inventory block in the world lets you access that inventory via networked functions. This allows you to use chests, barrels, or other types of item storage in your networks.

The storage via the ME Storage Bus is bidirectional, it can both insert, or extract items from the inventory block it is attached to as long as the ME storage bus has its required channel.

The UI allows you to control which items are selected as storable items, this selection has no effect on what items can be extracted once they are in the storage.

The storage bus will function with nearly any inventory block, including ME Interfaces, EFR barrels, JABBA Barrels, Storage Drawers, etc. They can also be used to route items passively into Buildcraft pipes.

If you place a storage bus on an ME Interface the storage bus will be able to interact with the full contents of the target network, unless that interface is configured to store items inside itself, in which case it will see those stored items.
data.title: Interfacing with Inventories

data.name: Interfacing with Machines
data.data:
The ME Interface is the only component which can be used as a part, or as a Block. Crafting an ME interface in either form by itself produces the other form. The thin form is useful if you want to provide several different interfaces in a single block of physical space, but each will need its own channel. The block form lets multiple other blocks connect to a single ME interface, using only one channel for the interface. The ME Interface acts as an in between when working with pipes, tubes, networks, or machines from other mods.

[note]If you're using a resource pack and the interface's GUI doesn't show up properly, you'll need to delete the assets\appliedenergistics2\textures\guis\interface.png file in your resourcepack zip file.[/note]
data.title: Interfacing with Machines

data.name: Large Molecular Assembler
data.data:
The Large Molecular Assembler is exactly how it sounds; a very quick molecular assembler with a much bigger inventory for crafting patterns.

This can handle up to 1024 crafts per second at the maximum energy usage making it up to 100x faster than a molecular assembler. Check out the Wiki for specifics: [url]https://wiki.gtnewhorizons.com/wiki/Large_Molecular_Assembler[/url]

The LMA controller hooks up directly to your main network in order to function, and all recipes must be placed inside input buses attached to the machine in order to be recognized. Will not require an output bus.

[note]Super Buses are highly recommended![/note]

[warn]This machine can absolutely wall-share, but be careful about the placement of your input bus or all machines may not be used.[/warn]

data.name: Level Maintainer
data.data:
The ME Level Maintainer is another cool addition of AE2FC. Choose an item or fluid and an amount to maintain, and the Level Maintainer will attempt to call patterns to keep crafting the item until it reaches the threshold you configured. You can also configure the crafting batch size.

[note]For fluid crafts, put in a fluid drop and don't drag from NEI.[/note]
data.title: Level Maintainer
data.tooltip:
Level Maintainer
Prequest requests:
Annihilation and Formation
AE Tier 1 Fluid Storage

data.name: Magical Minions
data.data: You can use the Wireless Golem Backpack to connect your golem to the network if it's close enough to an access point. See the Thaumonomicon for details.
data.title: Magical Minions

data.name: Magic Terminals
data.data:
The Arcane Crafting Terminal is the terminal version on the Arcane Workbench. It can hold a set of vis discount gear in its inventory in addition to a wand. You can also link a vis relay through the network to it to recharge the wand.

The Essentia Terminal Works like the Fluid Terminal, but for essentia.
data.title: Magic Terminals

data.name: Making Patterns Quick
data.data:
The Pattern Encoder will allow you to use NEI's shift-click ? button functionality to create a crafting pattern even if you don't have the appropriate items.

However, you can also drag the items from NEI to do the same thing, though much slower, because you have to look up each component. This is vastly less useful for processing patterns, since it's always 64 items though.
data.title: Making Patterns Quick

data.name: ME Controller
data.data:
The heart of your ME network. You can inject energy into here as well to power your network, but you probably want to save all available spaces for networking. Without this, you're limited to 8 channels.

This is a multiblock, and can be expanded up to 7x7x7, and can have 2 adjacent blocks in at most 1 axis, or it will be disabled. Whatever that means, just try it out, OK? You can only have one per network.

About channels:
Generally, every device uses a channel unless specified otherwise. If you don't have enough, that device will not function. If you can't determine what's causing your network problems, try looking at the lines on the smart and dense cables, or use a network visualizer.
data.title: ME Controller

data.name: ME in Your Cleanroom
data.data:
Wireless Connectors are a close range Quantum Network Bridge alternative.

Connections are point-to-point - you can't connect more than 2 blocks together. Each block will use 10 + distance * ln(distance^2 + 3) AE/t. Does not work across dimensions. Power needs to be provided on only one side. Up to 32 channels can be transferred through the connection. Can connect directly to dense cables. The Wireless Connector itself does not use any channels.

[note]Also, these are more TPS friendly than large chains of dense cables![/note]
data.title: ME in Your Cleanroom
data.tooltip:
ME in Your Cleanroom
Prequest requests:
Purifying the Impure
Getting Your First Processors
Illuminated Panels

data.name: Miscellaneous AE Items
data.data:
There are several AE items that aren't particularly useful, but probably deserve mention, so here they are:

§lCertus Tanks§r: They hold 32B and are portable and easy to make.

§lView Cell§r: Format in a Cell Workbench to filter what you see in a terminal (when they're installed in it)

§lCertus/Nether Quartz Cutting Knive§rs: Right-click to open interface and choose a name. The press can be used in the Inscriber to name stuff without using an anvil. You can also rename p2p tunnels and interfaces in world with the knife.

§lME Block Container§r: Holds only one type of item, but the amount of a 64k drive. Can place the item in world, or replace in a 1x1 or 3x3 area. Blocks replaced will be dumped in world. This will be horizontal or vertical depending on which side of a block you select. Shift-right-click air to change mode, right-click a block to activate mode.

§lCharged Quartz Fixture§r: Emits light at the same level as a torch, but fancier.

§lLight Detecting Fixture§r: Emits redstone signal based on light. Since it only starts at 7, it's not as useful as the Light Sensor.

§lME Upgrade (Tier 1/2/3)§r: If you're an OC person, there are 3 upgrades you can make to add access to your network from robots and drones.
T1: 0.5 access point range
T2: Normal access point range
T3: Unlimited range, any dim

§lEntropy Manipulator§r: Changes grass/dirt/dried dirt into each other, or starts fires. Or melts ice. Useless.

§lMatter Cannon§r: Shoots Matter Balls made in the Matter Condenser. Put it in an ME Chest or Drive and put items in a Terminal to fill. Decent I guess? But it destroys blocks every time you use it, so... Well, I guess you could use it with Paint Balls?

§lColor Applicator§r: Use dye items or Paint Balls (more efficient) to dye stuff. You can dye cables, or anything Forge-compatible, like wool or glass. Place items inside like the Matter Cannon. You can cycle through the colors by holding shift and right-clicking, or scrolling the mouse wheel. If you use snow balls, you can remove paint instead. You can also use it in a dispenser.

§6§lWalrus§r: It's a walrus, what were you expecting?
data.title: Miscellaneous AE Items

data.name: Moar Patterns!
data.data:
You may have noticed that the ME Interface's GUI is different than before. That is because with this card you can have more patterns, adding 9 more per card up to a total of 36. HOWEVER, it also uses 4 times the energy for every item when crafting, and this is multiplicative for each new card. If doing large crafts, make sure you have some dense energy cells ready.

So basically: (sum of amounts of items in the pattern) * config multiplier (which is 10 for GTNH). With cards, it's also multiplied by 4^(number of upgrades)

E.g: (wood log -> planks) in the interface w/o upgrades would draw: 1*10 AE units, which is 5 EU (remember 1 EU = 2 AE)
(9 charcoal -> charcoal block) compressor recipe in the interface with 3 upgrades will draw 9*10*4^3*0.5 = 2070 EU, but only 45EU without any cards

They're kind of expensive, so consider holding off if you can't afford the material or EU costs. If you remove it, all the extra patterns will pop out, so be careful of that when moving your stuff.
data.title: Moar Patterns!

data.name: Need More Information?
data.data:
A brand-new tool for you, amigo.

This little buddy not only has a larger card slot than the normal one, but also can show more information about your network storage.

Clicking the component icon can switch between ITEM, FLUID, and ESSENTIA details.

[warn]NOTE:
| unit | range |
| B | 0~2^10 |
| KB | 2^10~2^20 |
| MB | 2^20~2^30 |
| GB | 2^30~2^40 |
| TB | 2^40~2^50 |
| PB | 2^50~2^60 |
| EB | 2^60~2^70 |
| ZB | 2^70~2^80 |
| YB | 2^80~2^90 |
| BB | over 2^90 |[/warn]
data.title: Need More Information?
data.tooltip:
Need More Information?
Prequest requests:
64k Component
Tools of the Trade

data.name: Oceans in a Bottle
data.data: After managing to create an artificial universe capable of storing near-infinite amounts of items, you applied this same technology to your Fluid Digital Singularity Cell to create this truly magnificent piece of tech. This allows you to store up to 5 different types of fluids without the universe collapsing in on itself.
data.title: Oceans in a Bottle
data.tooltip:
Oceans in a Bottle
Prequest requests:
Another Digital Singularity
UXV Circuits

data.name: Optimizing Patterns in Late Game!
data.data:
You have probably already seen the button called §6Optimize Patterns§r when making an order in your AE system, now it's time to put it in the good use!

To unlock this feature, just add a Pattern Optimization Matrix block to your AE system (you only need one).

§l# What does it do?
§r
This feature allows you to multiply patterns that are needed in large amounts.

1. After calculating a big order, just click §6Optimize Patterns§r and you will be welcomed by a new window.
2. There you specify how much you wish for a singular pattern to be ordered (maximum amount of steps), we recommend putting it at 1000 or 100, [warn]remember that over-optimizing patterns could lead to longer waiting times[/warn]. At this point, you can also disable singular patterns from optimization by clicking on them, but there shouldn't be any unwanted patterns anyway if you already excluded them by toggling a button in unwanted interfaces.

3. Click §6Optimize§r and you are done! Try ordering again to see the changes in pattern steps

All changes are [warn]permanent and can't be reverted automatically[/warn] so make sure that you have excluded all unwanted interfaces (the §6Allow Pattern Optimization§r button is §7GRAY§r) like:
- Single Assembly Line interfaces
- Extreme Crafting interfaces
- And any interface that doesn't have (almost)infinite buffer at the other side (inf. chest/storage cells)
Patterns are only multiplied by powers of 2, so your AAL patterns should be safe.

[note]If you are still confused about maximum order steps here's an example:
Ordering an EOH calculates that it will need 1,000,008 UHV superconductors crafted (41667 steps, 24 UHV SC patterned), now you proceed to optimize patterns and specify that you wish it to do 1000 steps maximum, it will multiply your pattern 64 times to achieve that goal (41667 / 64 ~= 652 which is lower or equal to 1000). After clicking optimize, UHV SC pattern will now output 1536 UHV SC (24 before).[/note]
data.title: Optimizing Patterns in Late Game!
data.tooltip:
Optimizing Patterns in Late Game!
Prequest requests:
My Eyes Hurt! #1
Recipe Patterns

data.name: Ordering Essentia
data.data:
The Distillation Pattern Encoder allows you to automatically melt down items in your alchemical furnace to provide essentia.
First, place something that is already scanned in the device, along with a blank pattern. You can create the pattern by clicking the button, or click the different aspects to select one that is not the highest. This will create a pattern of item -> essentia. Then use an ME Interface pointing at a furnace with the pattern in it. You can now craft that type of essentia the same way you would a normal craft, but through the Essentia Terminal.

[warn]There isn't a way to have the system craft essentia on demand for a craft, unfortunately.[/warn]
data.title: Ordering Essentia

data.name: Ore Dictionary Output
data.data:
The ME ore dictionary export card will attempt to push the configured item/fluid [From the same ore dictionary] from the ME network into a machine or other input inventory. To configure an item/liquid, type in the item's name [e.g. if you want to export all ores put "ore*"]. The rate of export is very fast.

[note]PS: Use crushed* & !crushedPurified* & !crushedCentrifuged* to get any crushed ore, but not ore that has been washed, then crushed (to get purified) or run through the thermal centrifuge.[/note]

The card can be used in more devices, and causes less lag, but works in a similar way. Put it inside a bus and set the filter using the T looking button that appears. The standalone bus is no longer craftable.
data.title: Ore Dictionary Output
data.tooltip:
Ore Dictionary Output
Prequest requests:
Extracting Items From the Network

data.name: Out of Polytetrafluoroethylene? Turn on the LCR!
data.data: It's basically the same as a fluid detector cover, except it detects based on what's in your network. Click a cell into the center to specify, and an empty hand to clear.
data.title: Out of Polytetrafluoroethylene? Turn on the LCR!
data.tooltip:
Out of Polytetrafluoroethylene? Turn on the LCR!
Prequest requests:
Redstone Based on Storage Level

data.name: Pattern Terminal
data.data:
A specialized version of the ME crafting terminal designed to encode blank patterns into encoded patterns.

Lets you browse the contents of your network like other terminals, but also contains an area for designing patterns. There are two modes for pattern encoding. Crafting patterns, and processing patterns. Processing patterns are designed for use with machines that do not use standard crafting recipes - such as furnaces, or other machines. To select between modes, click the button to the right of the interface: when it shows a standard crafting table, it will create crafting patterns, and when it shows a furnace, it will create processing patterns.

For crafting patterns ("Crafts..."), you specify the input crafting materials on a standard 3x3 crafting grid, and the output materials are determined automatically.

For processing patterns ("Creates..."), you specify the input materials and output materials, including quantity, by placing stacks of items in the interface. If a processing operation is not guaranteed to succeed (such as secondary products from some machines), it will not work correctly as a processing pattern.

When designing crafting patterns you can click the output to extract a crafted item as long as you have the materials required to craft the item.
Don't forget to enable oredict substitution where needed.
data.title: Pattern Terminal

data.name: Perfecting Crystal Growth
data.data: The crystal growth chamber is used for fast crystal growth, and it is possible to increase its speed by installing acceleration cards in an upgrade slot. It works more like a normal device, with the crystals growing in its internal inventory. Unlike the more primitive versions, it doesn't use power when not in use. It also doesn't use a channel.
data.title: Perfecting Crystal Growth

data.name: Portable Digital Storage
data.data:
They're exactly what they sound like.

The first is for items and acts like a terminal. It can hold 4,032 of a single item.

The second is for liquids, and acts like the fluid terminal. It can hold 128 buckets of a single liquid.

It costs AE to put things in, take them out, or have the interface open. Use the Wireless Charger from EIO if you don't want it to take forever.
data.title: Portable Digital Storage
data.tooltip:
Portable Digital Storage
Prequest requests:
Storing Your ME Data

data.name: Providing Essentia on Demand
data.data:
The Essentia and Infusion Providers both do basically the same thing, send essentia to a device that requests it for crafting.

The Essentia Provider needs to be next to the device, it's mostly for the Thaumatorium. Since it's effectively a magic ME Interface, you can also use it instead of an Essentia Import Bus next to your Alembics or the Advanced Alchemical Furnace.

The Infusion Provider is for devices that draw essentia through the air, like the Runic Matrix (infusion) or Overchanting Table. It doesn't need to be next to the device.

They both obviously need the essentia they request to be accessible by the network to work.
data.title: Providing Essentia on Demand
data.tooltip:
Providing Essentia on Demand
Prequest requests:
Diffusion and Coalescence

data.name: Pulling Essentia Into the Network
data.data: Attach to either Alembics or the output of the Advanced Alchemical Furnace. If that doesn't work, have them pipe to a jar and import from there. You can finally get rid of your shifty-eyed golems.
data.title: Pulling Essentia Into the Network
data.tooltip:
Pulling Essentia Into the Network
Prequest requests:
Emptying Tanks

data.name: Purifying the Impure
data.data:
The purified versions of Nether, Certus and Fluix crystals can be grown from seeds made in the assembler from crystal dust and sand.

They can be grown in-world for free by dropping them in water, or at a much faster rate in a GT Autoclave.

[note]Distilled water reduces the recipe time in the Autoclave by half.[/note]
data.title: Purifying the Impure

data.name: Quantum Bridging Your Outposts
data.data:
A Quantum Network Bridge allows you to connect faraway places to your main AE network, even in other dimensions. So you can shove that pollution producing Mega EBF in the Void where it belongs, but still use it from the safety of your main base. To create this, you'll need a Quantum Link Chamber surrounded by Quantum Rings. Then put a Quantum Entangled Singularity in the link chamber, and connect to one of the 4 Quantum Rings around it with a fluix cable. They cost around 1000EU/t for each ring.

You can power the other side from the first, but you need to jumpstart it first, so bring an energy cell when setting it up. Remember that it's part of the same network, so you can only have one controller, and you're still limited by the channels of the cable you connected with, so you may wish to use the P2P Tunnel to bring more across.

If you use several, you may wish to rename the QESs.
data.title: Quantum Bridging Your Outposts
data.tooltip:
Quantum Bridging Your Outposts
Prequest requests:
Quantum Entangled Singularities

data.name: Quantum Entangled Singularities
data.data:
To make an entangled pair for usage in the quantum ring, put the Singularity and Enderpearl Dust on the ground, then use an explosion (Tiny TNT works well) to create two Quantum Entangled Singularities.

[note]QESs are each a unique pair and will only work with one another.[/note]
data.title: Quantum Entangled Singularities
data.tooltip:
Quantum Entangled Singularities
Prequest requests:
Singular Singularities Signify Something

data.name: Quantum Storage
data.data:
Now you §ocould§r connect Quantum Chests to your ME System with Storage Buses, and maybe you are already doing that. But why not use all your new technology to make a Quantum Storage Cell?

It only takes a single item type, but you can store more than a billion items! That surely must be enough, right? RIGHT?
data.title: Quantum Storage

data.name: Recipe Patterns
data.data: Save patterns onto these to do autocrafting. They go into molecular assemblers and ME interfaces.
data.title: Recipe Patterns

data.name: Redstone Based on Storage Level
data.data: This device will turn on (or off) a redstone signal based on how much of an item you specify (or energy in the network if you select the mode) you have in your network. Left-click an item into the space between the 1000 numbers to add, click again while holding nothing to remove.
data.title: Redstone Based on Storage Level

data.name: Short Guide - A Basic AE2 System
data.data:
So you've unlocked AE2, but don't know how to use it? Not to worry, that's what this questline is for. For a basic (and not completely useless) ME system, make the items on the right first. After you go through the quests to get them normally of course.

[note]You could technically make one with an ME Chest, but there's no advantage over using a regular chest.[/note]

Connect power to the Energy Acceptor, place the ME Drive next to it, place a Fluix Cable on top of the ME Drive connect the ME Terminal to the cable. Just put in the Storage cells, and you're done! Remember you need a Network Tool to see how much power it actually uses. Also, it lets you pick up stuff easier.

To save power, let's do a little extra work. Place the Pressure Plate two spaces in front of the ME Terminal, place redstone next to it and beside the Energy Acceptor. Remove the EA and place a Fluix Cable there, and then place the ME Toggle Bus between the Drive and where the Energy Acceptor will be. Then plunk that back down and re-power it. This will cause it to only connect (and thus use power) when you stand on the plate. This tiny network uses about 38 EU by itself, so you should understand that an ME system is not cheap either in materials or power.

You should make either 1k or 4k storage cells to put into your ME Drive.
data.title: Short Guide - A Basic AE2 System
data.tooltip:
Short Guide - A Basic AE2 System
Prequest requests:
Cables

data.name: Short Guide - Autocrafting
data.data:
This is the main purpose of AE2, so let's get to it. Plunk down the Crafting Storage and Molecular Assembler, connect the Pattern Terminal to a cable, and attach the ME Interface to the MA (make sure it has power from another side). You could run it without a ME Interface, but you can only do one recipe then. Place a Blank Pattern in the Pattern Terminal, and add the recipe for a Crafting Table, then click the arrow to save it to the pattern. Put this in the ME Interface and you can now request a craft of it. (if the items are in the network, otherwise it'll fail obviously)

For processing patterns (machines, anything not regular 3x3 crafting) click the button on the right. You'll need to specify all I/O for it yourself. You can use this on an ME Interface on a furnace (for example), combined with an ME Import Bus to collect the results. If it's a machine that auto-ejects (like multis) you can use a ME Interface to collect the results much faster (and with less lag).
data.title: Short Guide - Autocrafting

data.name: Short Guide - External Storage
data.data:
Drawers are great, right? Well, let's connect your ME system to a bank of them. Set up some drawers nearby with a controller attached. Then place an ME Storage Bus against the controller and set the priority to +1. This will prioritize I/O to the drawer controller. Lock your drawers before they fill with random stuff. Now you have access to the whole thing! Great for the results of mining, and anything else you have thousands of, while keeping your ME system relatively empty.

You can also connect to chests and other things if you want. You can use an Ender Chest to send stuff into your network, which will then send it to the drawers, but you'll have stuff entering and exiting constantly, so it'll mess up your view in the Terminal. You can use filtered view cells, or process them before they go into your ME network (or in a different one) and/or send them to the DC directly via another EC. It depends on what you want to do and what it is.

[warn]Using the drawer controller with large amounts of I/O will tank TPS! If you're on a server, do not use drawer cubes, or expect the possibility of it being deleted or you getting banned.[/warn]
data.title: Short Guide - External Storage
data.tooltip:
Short Guide - External Storage
Prequest requests:
Interfacing with Inventories

data.name: Short Guide - P2P
data.data:
One of the more complicated parts of AE2, you'll need to understand this to really get anywhere with the mod. First, replace your EA with an ME Controller. Now you have a bunch more channels to work with. Place the P2P Bus against one of the sides and then connect some cables to it to a place a bit away. Make sure to send power to this cable with an EA or Quartz Fiber, but NOT a normal cable, this is now a separate network, and that would cancel that. Connect the second P2P Bus to the other end, and then place at least 1 Dense Cable coming off of it. Shift-right-click your 1st P2P Bus, then right-click the 2nd. They're now connected, and there are 2 channels being used on your subnetwork, while you have the full 32 from the side of your Controller to use. For each subnetwork that doesn't have an ME Controller, you can send 4 sides, or 128 channels. I'm sure you can understand how useful this is, right?

There's lots more to understand about AE2, but you should probably either experiment, read the quests, or watch a video for more than the basics.
data.title: Short Guide - P2P

data.name: Singular Singularities Signify Something
data.data:
Quest names are hard sometimes, ok? To make a Singularity (for the Quantum Network Bridge), you'll need to dump 512,000 items into the Matter Condenser set to Singularity Mode, while using a 64k component or higher.

These singularities have a few purposes. Primarily they are used in creating quantum entangled singularities for the quantum ring, but they can also be used to create void cells and a couple other useful items.
data.title: Singular Singularities Signify Something

data.name: Smart cables
data.data: Smart cables are better than glass or covered cables because you can visually see many channels are in use.
data.title: Smart cables

data.name: Something to Put Your Components in
data.data:
An empty storage container, you can insert the vanilla AE2 storage cell parts into it to create a usable storage cell.

You can also craft it with the storage components when making them to skip combining them.
data.title: Something to Put Your Components in
data.tooltip:
Something to Put Your Components in
Prequest requests:
AE Tier 1 Item Storage

data.name: Speeding Up Growth
data.data: Used to accelerate the process of purifying crystals, which allows you to create pure certus quartz crystal, pure nether quartz crystal and pure fluix crystal. Must be powered by an ME Network via the sides with the +, and consumes a steady 8 ae/t while plugged in. Crystal Seeds must be in an adjacent water block to be affected - the seeds will shimmer more rapidly when in the presence of a powered crystal growth accelerator. These do not use a channel.
data.title: Speeding Up Growth

data.name: Spring Cleaning
data.data:
So, when you first started AE, maybe you dumped a bunch of your items into 1k drives, but now you want to clean them up, or empty them to reuse them in making higher tier ones. The ME IO Port will allow you to fill or empty your drives by connecting to the rest of the network.

You can use the Cell Workbench to format your drives, so they'll only contain the stuff you want. Remember, more item types mean less space overall. You can set them to lapis for example, then put them in the ME IO Port with the transfer direction to the drive to fill it with only that item. Don't put in an unformatted drive while using storage drawers to store tons of stuff! If you want to move your stuff around, put in new drives, then empty old ones, or disconnect your storage drawers temporarily.

You can use the Workbench to format fluid drives too, and even use cells instead of buckets.

Cell Workbenches do not connect to the network, so they don't need a channel.
data.title: Spring Cleaning

data.name: Starting Your AE2 Journey
data.data:
§nApplied Energistics 2 is an integral part of GTNH gameplay.
§r
AE2 is the primary networking and logistics management mod in GTNH for Items, Fluids, and Crafting. You will use it starting from EV and onward for most automations you perform. Given the sheer density of this modpack there are a variety of unique tools and features added specifically to aid in your adventure. Most of these tools are covered in this quest tab.

There is a lot to learn, but don't feel overburdened! Your abilities will continue to grow the more time you spend with it. There are a wide variety of helpful resources to take advantage of in addition to this book when it comes to learning:

§2§2§1§b§r§21. The Wiki:§r§r§o§o §o§o§r[url]§o§o§rhttps://wiki.gtnewhorizons.com/wiki/Applied_Energistics_2[/url]

§r- The Wiki has a lot of great starter information on what various systems do. They also have a lot of machine specific automation tutorials so be sure to check the Wiki if you're struggling or want a point of reference.


§b§r§22. The Discord: §o§r[url]https://discord.gg/gtnh[/url]

§r- The Discord is full of experienced AE2ers', check out #ae2-help to find plenty of people who will take time to help you figure something out.


§b§r§23. Video Tutorials: §r[url]§o§rhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LUYVmIAEC-I[/url]

§r- There are a lot of great GTNH content creators who make high quality video tutorials for this. Here is a link to AE2 Fundamentals by IX. There's an advanced version as well.
data.title: §5§lStarting Your AE2 Journey
data.tooltip:
Starting Your AE2 Journey
Prequest requests:
Tier 4 (EV)
Fallen From the Sky
Quartzite Veins

data.name: Stocking Fluids
data.data:
Works like stocking input bus but for fluids.

[note]You need only one to complete the quest.[/note]
data.title: Stocking Fluids

data.name: Storing Essentia in Jars? Why, again?
data.data:
So apparently you can attach this to a void/oblivion jar and have it void overflow if you set the priority low. Neat, huh?

What? Store essentia in jars? Seriously? I guess you could, if you really wanted to, or if there were new, larger jars...
data.title: Storing Essentia in Jars? Why, again?
data.tooltip:
Storing Essentia in Jars? Why, again?
Prequest requests:
Interfacing with Tanks

data.name: Storing Your ME Data
data.data:
A block designed to do one thing, store storage cells. This block holds 10 storage cells so you can tightly pack your storage into a very small space. ME drives show their contents and the storage cell status on the front of the drive face.

Red - Indicates the storage cell is full.
Orange - Indicates the storage cell cannot hold any more types, but it can store more items.
Green - Indicates the cell can hold more types, or more items.
Black - Indicates there is no channel, or power is offline.

It's important to note, that without an ME Network this block does nothing. It's only useful when combined with a way to input, and output items, and requires 2 AE/t power to function, and additional power for each storage cell stored inside it.

About Priority: Many devices in AE2 have a priority setting, this determines what gets items first. This is useful in some situations, but not so much in others. Higher number = higher priority.
data.title: Storing Your ME Data
data.tooltip:
Storing Your ME Data
Prequest requests:
Getting Your First Processors
Cables

data.name: Super Stock Replenisher
data.data:
The Super Stock Replenisher is an incredibly useful item, especially for those pesky loop automations!

To use, put a storage cell in the empty slot (item vs fluid & type amount do not matter) and you can set up to 63 items & 9 fluids to be stocked by the machine. The total quantity of both items and fluids are determined by the byte size of the storage cell.

When an item / fluid is stocked, it will pull it from the ME network it is attached to and those items / fluids will become invisible to your network. You can then use a storage bus to make these items visible to a subnet. Items will not be able to re-enter the block once pulled out.

[note]When an item or fluid is erased from the stocker or when the stocker is broken, everything will return to the network the stocker was attached too, so no need to panic about losing items.[/note]
data.title: Super Stock Replenisher

data.name: Thaumometric Essentia Cell
data.data: After meddling with the 4th Dimension, you've finally discovered a way to access its unlimited Essentia supply. The Thaumometric Essentia Cell is your tool for extracting Essentia from this boundless source—think of it as your unlimited magic credit card.
data.title: Thaumometric Essentia Cell
data.tooltip:
Thaumometric Essentia Cell
Prequest requests:
A Taste of Their Own Medicine
And Another Digital Singularity
UIV Field Generator

data.name: The Fluid Terminal
data.data: The ME Fluid Terminal allows you to directly input and output fluids from the network using buckets, cells, and other fluid-containing items. Put a filled cell (or other item) in the bottom left to have the contents deposited into the network, and the cell moved to the output slot. For the reverse, select a fluid and insert an empty cell, and it'll fill it.
data.title: The Fluid Terminal

data.name: To Link P2P Buses
data.data:
A small item that can be used to store, copy, and paste settings. Shift-right-click on a configurable object to save the settings onto the memory card, then right-click on any other block of the same type to paste the settings. Shift-right-click on a non-configurable object (or the air) to clear. They are also used to link the input P2P tunnel to the corresponding output P2P tunnels. They can also link Vis Relays to compatible devices.

If you're doing more advanced operations in a large network of P2Ps, it's recommended you use the advanced memory card. It has a helpful UI that allows you to visualize and set names, inputs, and outputs of P2P tunnels.

[note]Remember P2Ps can only have 1 input! The only exception being fluid P2Ps whose input can function as an output and whose outputs can function as an input.[/note]
data.title: To Link P2P Buses
data.tooltip:
To Link P2P Buses
Prequest requests:
Bundled AE Channels

data.name: Tools of the Trade
data.data:
The Network Tool is AE2's main utility tool.

Right-click on a network to see the power usage, and what makes up the network.
Right-click on air to interact with its inventory to store cards or turn facades transparent.
Shift-right-click to remove fixtures (import bus, interface, etc.) that don't take up a full block without removing the cable, or remove any AE block immediately the same way.

The Network Visualizer does exactly what it says, it allows you to visualize the channels of your network. First, right-click a network to select it. At first you'll see everything, but you can change the modes by holding shift and scrolling the mouse wheel up or down to see different things. Remember that if you have a subnetwork, like one that P2P tunnels go through for example, those nodes won't show up since it's a different network, but the P2P tunnels entrances and exits will. This goes through solid objects, so you can look at your whole base.
data.title: Tools of the Trade
data.tooltip:
Tools of the Trade
Prequest requests:
Storing Your ME Data

data.name: Ultimate Parallelization...
data.data: Allows for parallelization of a single interface, you don't have to copy patterns for multiple interfaces anymore.
data.title: §6§lUltimate Parallelization...

data.name: Universe in a Bottle
data.data: Those Digital Singularities, while offering a vast amount of space, felt constraining with their ability to store only one type of item... So you came up with something different this time. Having reached the peak of technology, you managed to create and contain an Artificial Universe within a Storage Cell. This allows you to store up to 63 different types of items without the universe collapsing in on itself.
data.title: Universe in a Bottle
data.tooltip:
Universe in a Bottle
Prequest requests:
A Digital Singularity
UXV Circuits

data.name: Visualizing How Much Your Stuff
data.data:
The ME Storage Monitor allows you to visualize how much of an item you have. For example you can tell if you're running low on circuits and should make more, or how a long crafting process is proceeding. There are a couple of ways to use them.

Right-click with item: Will display the current level of that item if not locked.
Right-click with empty hand: Will reset the display if not locked.
Right-click with AE2 wrench or network tool: Will toggle the lock.


The ME Conversion Monitor is the upgraded version of the ME Storage Monitor. It adds the ability to directly withdraw from or store items into the ME Network. It has the normal interactions, plus more.

Shift-right-clicking with item: Attempts to insert the item stack into the network. This works even if it's not the displayed item!
Shift-double-right-clicking: Attempts to insert all item stacks of the type displayed into the network.
Right-clicking (while locked): Attempts to pull out a stack of the item displayed.
data.title: Visualizing How Much Your Stuff
data.tooltip:
Visualizing How Much Your Stuff
Prequest requests:
Illuminated Panels

data.data:
With the ability to bend spacetime at your will, you can prevent fluids and electronics from interacting.

Fluid containing patterns can be processed.

[note]Otherwise it works like crafting input bus.[/note]

data.name: Wireless 2.0
data.data:
This is the good wireless terminal. It allows you to combine 6 different types of terminals into one ultimate terminal for usage on the go; Crafting, Patterning, Fluid, Essentia, Interface, & Level Emitter.

If you make the full version, it even allows you to program large fluid processing patterns without needing LuV parts to make the terminal first.

[note]Recommended to set a keybind for this so you don't need to keep it in your hotbar.[/note]
data.title: Wireless 2.0
data.tooltip:
Wireless 2.0
Prequest requests:
Wireless Applied Energistics Terminal
Singular Singularities Signify Something

data.name: Wireless 3.0
data.data: This upgrade allows unlimited range. You don't even need a Wireless Access Point!
data.title: Wireless 3.0

data.name: Wireless Applied Energistics Terminal
data.data:
After you link up the wireless terminal in the ME security terminal, it grants portable access to the ME network. Put it into a charger to recharge it.

Holds 1.6m AE in its battery and drains 1 AE/t for each block you are away from the nearest ME wireless access point.

Charge your Wireless Terminals (and the successors) with an EIO Wireless Charger if you don't want to wait a century for them to charge.
data.title: Wireless Applied Energistics Terminal
data.tooltip:
Wireless Applied Energistics Terminal
Prequest requests:
Wireless Setup
Dense Boys

data.name: Wireless HUBs
data.data:
The Wireless Connector also has a HUB upgrade! These Wireless HUBs can be linked to many wireless connectors at once so you won't need to spam a chunk of 1:1 connectors into one spot. Keep in mind there is still a 32 channel limitation.

[note]Great for placing on controller faces![/note]
data.title: Wireless HUBs

data.name: Wireless Setup
data.data:
Allows you to configure which users, and what permissions the users have with the ME System. By existing it enforces permissions on the usage of the system.

The security system does not prevent destructive tampering, removing cables / machines or breaking of drives. If you need to protect your system from physical vandalism you will need another form of physical security. This block provides network level security.

The player who places the ME security terminal has full control over the network and cannot exclude themselves any rights. By adding a blank biometric card you define a default behavior for every player who has no biometric card registered.

In addition to security on the software layer, you can link up your wireless terminal with the network and access it wirelessly.

If you have one on your main network, your subnets may also need one to have access to your main network, but this is not always the case depending on how you set it up.


The ME Wireless Access Point wireless access via a wireless terminal. Range and power usage is determined based on the number of wireless boosters installed into the ME wireless access point. A network can have any number of ME wireless access points with any number of wireless boosters in each one, allowing you to optimize power usage and range by altering your setup.
data.title: Wireless Setup

data.name: ...with Fluid Support!
data.data: Now with fluid support!
data.title: §6§l...with Fluid Support!

data.name: Yet Another Singularity?!?!
data.data:
Ever wanted to order 10 million billion billion chests and noticed that your crafting storage was just not big enough?

Well, here is your solution, provided to you by the good folks over at GTNHCorp (Name Pending).

§c§rThe §cSingularity Crafting Storage§r has a storage of 9,223,372,036,854,775,807 Bytes, which, if you can't read numbers, is a lot.

Enjoy crafting one :) You'll need to kill some Chaos Guardians for it.
data.title: Yet Another Singularity?!?!

Yet Another Singularity?!?!

data.name: Advanced Detector Rail
data.data: Now that you have a cargo manager you need a specific rail so that your cart can interact with it. Just place it next to the cargo manager, depending on the color of the side it is on you will have to adjust settings in the cargo manager GUI.
data.title: Advanced Detector Rail

data.name: A Simple Cart
data.data:
In order to create or customize your cart you need a hull to attach your desired upgrades to. The wooden one can be used for really simple applications, but to farm wheat or wood, you need at least an iron one.

§c§lWARNING: §r§cUnprotected carts can be knocked off their rails by lightning. Cover the area with glass (or any solid block) to prevent carts from disappearing.

Also, make sure to keep your cart in one chunk, or use chunkloaders covering the whole area the cart works within. Loading/unloading chunks may cause carts to disappear or duplicate.
data.title: A Simple Cart

data.name: Automated (un-)Loading
data.data: You can fill and empty your cart manually, but it's a lot more convenient to automate item transfer, isn't it?
data.title: Automated (un-)Loading

data.name: Cart Modules: Coal Power
data.data: Your cart needs power, obviously. A cart can be powered via coal, solar, or lava. But for now you have to use a simple coal engine.
data.title: Cart Modules: Coal Power
data.tooltip:
Cart Modules: Coal Power
Prequest requests:
A Simple Cart

data.name: Cart modules: Digging
data.data: Want to automate digging for ores? A drill head made out of iron is the cheapest alternative.
data.title: Cart modules: Digging

data.name: Cart Modules: Farming
data.data: Unfortunately, the basic farmer can't farm anything besides wheat, carrots and potatoes. It's not expensive at all, and probably the cheapest solution to give your automated food production a nice boost.
data.title: Cart Modules: Farming

data.name: Cart Modules: More Storage
data.data: After you craft side chests you can add more different chests to the cart. Some sides are reserved for tools so no chest can be placed there.
data.title: Cart Modules: More Storage
data.tooltip:
Cart Modules: More Storage
Prequest requests:
Cart Modules: Storage

data.name: Cart Modules: Solar Power
data.data: Your cart needs power, obviously. A cart can be powered via coal, solar or lava. If you are able to make solar panels you can power your cart with the sun.
data.title: Cart Modules: Solar Power
data.tooltip:
Cart Modules: Solar Power
Prequest requests:
Power of the Sun
A Simple Cart

data.name: Cart Modules: Storage
data.data: A basic cart can't hold any items, so you need to attach special chests to it.
data.title: Cart Modules: Storage

data.name: Cart Modules: Thermal Engine
data.data: Your cart needs power, obviously. A cart can be powered via coal, solar or lava. Why not power your cart with lava?
data.title: Cart Modules: Thermal Engine
data.tooltip:
Cart Modules: Thermal Engine
Prequest requests:
A Simple Cart

data.name: Cart Modules: Wood Cutter
data.data: The basic wood cutter will break after a while, but you never have to replace it. It can easily be repaired with diamonds.
data.title: Cart Modules: Wood Cutter
data.tooltip:
Cart Modules: Wood Cutter
Prequest requests:
A Simple Cart

data.name: Chips
data.data:
Now you need to make some chips to use in those interface pipes. These are useless on their own but essential for crafting the others.

Now would be a good time to look into IC2 crops to get all the dyes you will need for your advanced chips.

[note]If NEI's bookmarks are blocking you on the left, you can turn it off (O) until that gets fixed.[/note]
data.title: Chips

data.name: Crafting Chip
data.data:
The crafting chip does exactly what it says. It's not just for default crafting. You can use it with GT machines. Just put in the matrix that it should insert and the output is what it should extract. A great use for them is in combination with fluid canners or super tanks for filling cells.


[note]While these chips are really powerful for your PRT system they become a lag hazard relatively quickly, so be careful.[/note]
data.title: Crafting Chip

data.name: Dealing with H2S
data.data:
Now let's convert all that H2S into sulfuric acid. Hook up a chemical reactor to electricity, water and interface pipe. Put inside an item responder chip set to accept H2S cells and extract empty cells. Distill that diluted sulfuric acid in distillery and store it in super tank.

Congratulations. You now have a completely automatic desulfurization of oil, automatic production of hydrogen and oxygen and you also store all that sulfuric acid.
data.title: Dealing with H2S

data.name: Desulfurizing Oil Automation
data.data: This quest line will show you how to automate desulfurizing of oil products. Return here once you have unlocked the LV distillery quest and have some polyethylene plates.
data.title: Desulfurizing Oil Automation
data.tooltip:
Desulfurizing Oil Automation
Prequest requests:
Item Stock Keeper Chip
Crafting Chip

data.name: Desulfurizing the Oil
data.data:
Now it's time to start the actual desulfurization. Use a chemical reactor of your choice, fill it with sulfuric light fuel and hook it to power. Now connect an interface pipe to it. Put an item stock keeper inside set to store 4 hydrogen cells. Then put in item extractor set to extract hydrogen sulfide and empty cells.

Go to your hydrogen storage super tank and put in a crafting chip set to make one hydrogen cell from one empty cell.

And that's all.
data.title: Desulfurizing the Oil

data.name: Does Anyone Even Still Use These?
data.data: If you do, they're now really good. I guess. They sound like it at least?
data.title: Does Anyone Even Still Use These?
data.tooltip:
Does Anyone Even Still Use These?
Prequest requests:
One Ingot, Infinite Power
Cart Modules: Solar Power
Cart Modules: Thermal Engine
Cart Modules: Coal Power

data.name: Dynamic Item Responder
data.data: The dynamic item responder chip behaves exactly like an item responder chip, but instead of you setting up which items it should accept, it looks in the chest what items are there and those items it will accept.
data.title: Dynamic Item Responder

data.name: Electrolyzing Water
data.data:
Now let's automate electrolyzing water into oxygen and hydrogen. You'll need hydrogen for tons of stuff including desulfurization, obtaining tungsten, and nitric acid production. Oxygen is also useful as I'm sure you noticed when making steel.

How to set it up:

Place the electrolyzer down and connect it to water and electricity. Place the 2 super tanks nearby. Set the electrolyzer to produce hydrogen gas and oxygen cells. Use normal GT fluid pipes to output the hydrogen gas into one super tank. That is now your hydrogen storage. Now connect interface pipes to all 3 machines.

For the electrolyzer put in item stock keeper set to keep 2 empty cells stored. Also put in extractor set to extract oxygen cells.

Now for the oxygen storage put it item responder chip set to accept oxygen cells and extractor set to extract empty cells.

Now put some empty cells inside your default storage chest and don't forget to have a broadcaster there.
data.title: Electrolyzing Water

data.name: Further Automation
data.data: If you want to load and unload a lot of different items from your cargo manager the pipes can get quite messy. The external distributor is a block you can place next to your cargo manager and it will help you to access different slots which you can specify in its GUI. Quite handy for pumping items in and out!
data.title: Further Automation

data.name: Interacting With Stuff
data.data:
That's all nice and all, but none of these pipes connect to chests and machines. What am I supposed to do with them?

I'm glad you asked. You are going to need a special pipe for that. This is a pipe you need to use to connect to machines and chests. You'll have to set it up with chips that we'll make soon.
data.title: Interacting With Stuff

data.name: Item Broadcaster
data.data:
The item broadcaster is a chip that tells everything in the pipe system what items it has in the connecting inventory and if another chip needs anything it will send it to them. Right-click it to set the items it will transmit. If you leave it empty and set to blacklist it will transmit everything.

Definitely use one in combination with an item overflow chip on your default storage chest. That way overflow will end up in the chest, but will be usable by the rest of your system.
data.title: Item Broadcaster

data.name: Item Extractor Chip
data.data:
This chip will extract items from the connecting inventory. The extracted items then look for pipes with item responder chips where there's a free space they could go. If they don't find any they will go to the overflow default storage chest.

If you want it to extract everything leave the filter empty and set it to blacklist.
data.title: Item Extractor Chip
data.tooltip:
Item Extractor Chip
Prequest requests:
Item Responder Chip
Item Overflow Chip

data.name: Item Overflow Chip
data.data:
This chip stores the items in a connected inventory. It designates a storage for items that have no other place to go. It is strongly recommended to have a default storage for items in every pipe system, otherwise bad stuff can happen. Best used with a large chest (diamond for example).

It seems to have some bugs though, so don't craft more than one without testing it first.

You might have to just use a normal item responder and add the items you want routed back to your overflow spot.
data.title: Item Overflow Chip

data.name: Item Responder Chip
data.data: This chip also stores items in connected inventory. It designates a storage for items that are set in the filter of this chip. They do not actively request for items, they only serve as a destination for items to go. You can open up the menu by right-clicking the chip. There you can set which items should it accept and the priority. Items will go to item responders with higher priority first.
data.title: Item Responder Chip

data.name: Item Stock Keeper Chip
data.data:
The item stock keeper looks at the connecting inventory and keeps item stocked in there. If the item is missing it will keep bothering item broadcasters every few seconds if they have the item and if they can send it. It's basically like an annoying child.

It is really useful though. Want a chest that will always have 64 cobble and dirt in it and if you take them they will get replaced? This guy is perfect for that job. It's great for keeping machines stocked. When stocking GT machines, the top left slot of the 3x3 is equal to the left slot of the machine. Want a chemical reactor that keeps 3 hydrogen cells ready to go to make ammonia, just add nitrogen? This is the chip for you.
data.title: Item Stock Keeper Chip

data.name: Junctions
data.data: So how do we deal with junctions then? We use these pipes. They are smart and they will send everything where it needs to go, so if you make a junction make sure you put this pipe there.
data.title: Junctions

data.name: Let's Get Some Pipes
data.data:
First we're gonna need some pipes to connect everything. Do not use these pipes in junctions or the items will choose which path to go at random and you don't want that.

[note]Keep in mind PR automation is laggy, so don't use it more than the minimum you can get away with on servers, wait until AE2 for that. In SP, do what you want, but keep in mind that AE2 is way more powerful.[/note]
data.title: Let's Get Some Pipes
data.tooltip:
Let's Get Some Pipes
Prequest requests:
Your First Electronic Circuit

data.name: More Tree Types
data.data: The standard wood cutter can only chop down (and replant) vanilla trees. If you want to use saplings from other mods however this add-on will come in handy. Who knows - maybe you're tired of clicking rubber trees with a treetap.
data.title: More Tree Types
data.tooltip:
More Tree Types
Prequest requests:
Cart Modules: Wood Cutter
Tier 2 (MV)

data.name: Request Pipe
data.data: This pipe lets you request stuff from the system. It shows all items that are available thanks to broadcast chips and even stuff that can be crafted thanks to crafting chips.
data.title: Request Pipe

data.name: Reward for Desulfurizing Automation
data.data:
The greatest reward is having your stuff automated if you've done everything correctly, but here's a reward for making it this far.

Some other setups to look at automating are making polyethylene and nitric acid.

With stock keeper chips you can always keep a set amount on-hand and when you pull out the cells to use elsewhere, your setup will automatically make more.
data.title: Reward for Desulfurizing Automation
data.tooltip:
Reward for Desulfurizing Automation
Prequest requests:
Dealing with H2S

data.name: Simple Storage System
data.data:
[warn]Using the drawer controller with large amounts of I/O will tank TPS! If you're on a server, do not use drawer cubes, or expect the possibility of it being deleted or you getting banned.[/warn]

Time to build a simple system to store your stuff. Place down the drawer controller and place the drawers around it. Connect the interface pipe to the drawer controller and put the dynamic item responder and broadcaster chips inside. Don't forget to set the broadcaster to transmit everything by leaving the filter empty and setting it to blacklist. Now you can request stuff from your storage and if you have a chest with a pipe and extractor chip everything you put inside will be sorted into the storage.
data.title: Simple Storage System

data.name: Small Reward
data.data: Here's a small reward for making all those chips.
data.title: Small Reward

data.name: Storing the Fluids
data.data:
First we should make a place to store all the fluids we'll use.

If you're interested what they'll be used for:
1 for oxygen
1 for hydrogen
1 for sulfuric acid
data.title: Storing the Fluids
data.tooltip:
Storing the Fluids

Your Oil is Too Crude? Refine it!
Desulfurizing Oil Automation

data.name: Your First Automation
data.data: Well, probably not the first, but definitely something big! You'll need a cart assembler first.
data.title: Your First Automation
data.tooltip:
Your First Automation
Prequest requests:
Avengers, Assemble!
Molten Redstone?
You're Gonna Hate This #1
You're Gonna Hate This #4

data.name: Abandoned
data.data: Abandoned are the next step up. Breed them from Oblivion and Nameless.
data.title: Abandoned

data.name: Aer
data.data: For Aer bees to appear, you must put an Air Crystal Cluster beneath the bee housing. They will produce Aer infused dust for you. Being nearby will grant a Swiftness buff. Breed them from two Windy.
data.title: Aer

data.name: Agrarian
data.data: Agrarian bees are supposed to help crops nearby grow. The effect isn't really that noticeable, is it? You'll have to be in a Plains-like biome for these to appear. Breed them from Farmerly and Industrious.
data.title: Agrarian

data.name: Aluminium
data.data: Aluminium isn't necessary until MV, but when you want it, you'll want lots. Requires block of Aluminium. Breed them from Nickel and Zinc.
data.title: Aluminium

data.name: Americium
data.data: A remarkable bee. If you thought americium can only be obtained from fusion you would be wrong.
data.title: Americium

data.name: Ancient
data.data: Ancient bees are the first step to the best oil bees in the game. Breed them from Diligent and Noble.
data.title: Ancient

data.name: Apatite
data.data: The Apatite bee requires an Apatite Block beneath it to breed. Its Seedy comb will make seed oil as well. Breed them from Ash and Coal.
data.title: Apatite

data.name: Aqua
data.data: Aqua requires a Water Crystal Cluster. It will produce Water infused dust. Staying nearby will clear potion effects, like drinking a bucket of milk. Might be useful for the clever industrial engineer! Breed them from two Watery.
data.title: Aqua

data.name: Arcane
data.data: Enchanting drops from Arcane bees are used to create Aromatic Lumps for use in the Swarmer. It has a higher chance of success than normal Royal Jelly. These bees are the other bedrock of the Magic Bees branch. Breed them from Esoteric and Mysterious.
data.title: Arcane

data.name: Arid
data.data: The Arid Bee species. Useless you say?
data.title: Arid

data.name: Aromatic Lump
data.data: Aromatic Lumps are twice as effective as Royal Jelly in an Alveary Swarmer. You'll need Enchanting Drops from Arcane bees and Pollen Clusters from Industrious bees.
data.title: Aromatic Lump

data.name: Arsenic
data.data: This deadly little princess will get you Arsenic, perfect for use in your circuits. Requires a Block of Arsenic. Breed them from Silver and Zinc.
data.title: Arsenic

data.name: Ash
data.data: A bee to make ashes? What insanity is this? At least you can get Large territory from them. You'll need to pay the Nether a visit. Breed them from Clay and Coal.
data.title: Ash

data.name: Austere
data.data: Another bee that requires an attentive beekeeper. Without an Apiarist suit, this bee will inflict creeper explosions on you. Watch you. It will require a hot or hellish biome with Arid humidity. Breed them from Modest and Frugal.
data.title: Austere

data.name: Avenging
data.data: Hatred distilled into its most violent form. Keep away from everything. Breed them from Vengeful and Vindictive.
data.title: Avenging

data.name: Aware
data.data: Not much to say about this bee. Breed them from Ethereal and Attuned.
data.title: Aware

data.name: Barren
data.data: The Barren Bee. Not much better.
data.title: Barren

data.name: Basic Bee Stats
data.data:
There are a couple of basic bees that have good stats you want to breed into your breeding stock.

Cave Dwelling - Rocky - This lets you put the bee housing underneath or inside. Handy for putting a chest on top for products.

Nocturnal - Rocky - This keeps your bees working all night long, and in the dark.

Rain Tolerant - Water - Keep producing even when it is raining.

High Fertility - Wintry - For breeding purposes, you want the maximum number of drones produced.

Keep in mind that specialty products from bees require the Jubilant state.
To be in this state, a bee needs to have its naturally preferred humidity and temperature. Just being able to work due to tolerance traits is not enough.

For example, a Salt bee needs Warm/Normal climate. Even if it has +- humidity and temp, it will not produce its Salt comb unless it is in a Warm/Normal climate. Use Alveary upgrades to make sure it is in its preferred temp/humidity.
data.title: Basic Bee Stats
data.tooltip:
Basic Bee Stats
Prequest requests:
Moron's Guide to Breeding Better Bees

data.name: Batty
data.data: Batty bees will spawn firebats. So prepare for battle. Their specialty is Gunpowder. Breed them from Skulking and Windy.
data.title: Batty

data.name: Blooming
data.data: A Blooming bee will bonemeal nearby saplings. This can definitely help your log and sapling production rate. They also provide the fastest pollination. Breed them from Industrious and Thriving.
data.title: Blooming

data.name: Blue
data.data: Blue princesses will provide a handy source of blue dye. Breed them from Forest and Diligent.
data.title: Blue

data.name: Breed some common bees
data.data:
To cross breed bees you need two different species of bees. One drone and one princess from different world-gen hives (Meadows and Forest as an example)

Bee Houses do not allow crossbreeding. You need an Apiary to crossbreed them to a new species. Certain frames will help this process. Shortening their lifespan means faster crosses. Increasing Mutation rate means getting mutations and thus rare bees quicker.

Common Bees produce Honey Combs every 2.2 minutes. Note that production times are an approximation based on the bee's base production speed and the product's rarity. They do not reflect actual production time.
